text:
So LFortran has a REPL now:
<https://twitter.com/lfortranorg/status/1367507839535640578>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/lfortranorg|@lfortranorg>: Thanks to <https://twitter.com/DominicPoerio|@DominicPoerio>, LFortran now has a multi-line REPL in a terminal (works on all platforms), and it uses the tokens to determine if the line is complete, so you only have to press Enter and it will automatically start a new line such as in the if statement below: <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Evpci-XUUAA3hbE.jpg>
attachments.text: Thanks to <https://twitter.com/DominicPoerio|@DominicPoerio>, LFortran now has a multi-line REPL in a terminal (works on all platforms), and it uses the tokens to determine if the line is complete, so you only have to press Enter and it will automatically start a new line such as in the if statement below: <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Evpci-XUUAA3hbE.jpg>

text: <https://lfortran.org/>

attachments.title: LFortran
attachments.text: Feature Highlights LFortran is in development, there are features that work today, and there are features that are being implemented. Works today Interactive, Jupyter support LFortran can be used as a Jupyter kernel, allowing Python/Julia-style rapid prototyping and an exploratory workflow (see the static or interactive example notebook). It can also be used from the command-line with an interactive prompt (REPL). Clean, modular design, usable as a library

text: it's _kinda_ a compiler, but it's more meant to be an interactive environment for fortran, it even runs in jupyter.  it's also very limited as it supports a small subset of fortran (and I believe only very recent standards).  it's _based_ on llvm, but it isn't an llvm project.  so saying llvm fortran it's calling julia "llvm julia" just because it uses julia
